body: Clang is required for building atom-shell, and you would also need to build [libchromiumcontent](https://github.com/brightray/libchromiumcontent) if you want to build everything from scratch.

As I pointed out in https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/2177, I'm aware that clang is required (although I'm not sure why GCC wouldn't be enough but I'm not hugely familiar with either).

The problem I see is that atom-shell (and by extension atom) are supposed to end up being cross-platform. Clang 3.4 is available on CentOS 6.5, however Clang 3.5 isn't by default.

Having tried (and failed) to build it myself, has have many other people, I find it somewhat premature to close this as a non-issue. If there isn't ever a way of building atom-shell for CentOS 6.5, this does seem like an issue to me.

Even stranger, why does atom pull pre-built Ubuntu binaries of atom-shell for Linux flavors?

Since you already have clang installed, you may need to set clang as your default compiler by setting `CC` and `CXX` to `clang` and `clang++` (I haven't tested since I don't have CentOS installed). Supporting multiple toolchains would increase lots of maintainance work, so currently only clang is supported as build toolchain on Linux. GCC >= 4.7 should also work though.

We provide pre-built binaries only for Ubuntu because Ubuntu and its forks are most widely used, providing binaries for other Linux distributions is also [on the plan](https://github.com/atom/atom-shell/issues/259), but it would take lots of work and for now there is no time allocated for it.

If your sole purpose is to make atom run on CentOS, we could ship `libstdc++.so.6` and `libc.so.6` along with atom-shell, just like how we solved the [`libudev.so` unfound](https://github.com/atom/atom-shell/commit/d9e1861aff327bbda78477eed44ac6392f6c03ad) problem.

Thanks a lot @zcbenz. I'm not currently in a position to try this out, but will do as soon as I can.

I wasn't aware of the `libudev.so` issue either, thanks for pointing it out.

@zcbenz Shipping all the dynamic libraries necessary to run (or even a statically compiled version of atom) would be a huge help while other hacking/backporting is taking place to get the from-source builds to be more flexible.

I tried a quick pass at this by:

Grabbing "Linux" release (which says nothing about which distros are supported and really should)
from https://github.com/atom/atom-shell/releases

Then grabbed Ubuntu packages from
http://packages.ubuntu.com/precise/libc6-amd64
http://packages.ubuntu.com/precise/lib64stdc%2B%2B6
(Extracted using `ar vx <package>.deb` , `tar zxf data.tar.gz` and pull out .so files/symlinks into atom directory)

Running atom (shell) then complained

```
libchromiumcontent.so: undefined symbol: gdk_window_get_screen
```

so I grabbed http://packages.ubuntu.com/precise/libgtk2.0-0 and tossed `libgdk-x11-2.0.so.0` (where gdk_window_get_screen is defined)

Now it segfaults. Given this is likely to get into some nasty GTK dependency issues, I don't think shipping with a boatload of dynamic libraries makes sense.

Is there something keeping atom-shell from building its binary statically? This is how most linux versions of programs deal with providing binaries that run on any linux distribution (Sublime Text is a familiar example).

Happy fun times.

The number of unmatched dependencies is absolutely crazy, but this is getting somewhere.

Python 2.7 needs to be installed (2.6 just doesn't seem to work for me):

```
wget --no-check-certificate http://python.org/ftp/python/2.7.6/Python-2.7.6.tgz
tar -xzf Python-2.7.6.tgz
cd Python-2.7.6
./configure --prefix=/usr/local --enable-unicode=ucs4 --enable-shared LDFLAGS="-Wl,-rpath /usr/local/lib"
make && make altinstall
```

Node 0.10.x and NPM need to be installed from source:

```
wget http://nodejs.org/dist/v0.10.28/node-v0.10.28.tar.gz
tar xzf node-v0.10.28.tar.gz
cd node-v0.10.28
./configure && make && make install
```

GCC 4.8 needs to be installed (make sure you remove any previous versions of GCC):

```
wget -O /etc/yum.repos.d/slc6-devtoolset.repo http://linuxsoft.cern.ch/cern/devtoolset/slc6-devtoolset.repo
yum install -y devtoolset-2
scl enable devtoolset-2 bash
```

Set the compiler:

```
export CC=/opt/rh/devtoolset-2/root/usr/bin/gcc
export CPP=/opt/rh/devtoolset-2/root/usr/bin/cpp
export CXX=/opt/rh/devtoolset-2/root/usr/bin/c++
```

Libnotify (and devel) require 0.7 (default on CentOS 6.5 is 0.5):

```
wget http://dl.fedoraproject.org/pub/fedora/linux/development/rawhide/x86_64/os/Packages/l/libnotify-0.7.6-1.fc21.x86_64.rpm
yum install -y libnotify-0.7.6-1.fc21.x86_64.rpm

wget http://dl.fedoraproject.org/pub/fedora/linux/development/rawhide/x86_64/os/Packages/l/libnotify-devel-0.7.6-1.fc21.x86_64.rpm
yum install -y libnotify-devel-0.7.6-1.fc21.x86_64.rpm
```

then:

```
python2.7 ./script/bootstrap.py
```

and:

```
python2.7 ./script/build.py
```

This works until the very last step (293/293), where it throws the following:

```
FAILED: /opt/rh/devtoolset-2/root/usr/bin/c++ -rpath \$ORIGIN -rdynamic -pthread -Wl,--no-keep-memory -o atom -Wl,--start-group obj/atom/app/atom.atom_main.o obj/vendor/node/deps/cares/libcares.a obj/vendor/breakpad/libbreakpad_client.a obj/vendor/node/deps/openssl/libopenssl.a obj/vendor/node/deps/zlib/libchrome_zlib.a obj/vendor/node/libnode_lib.a obj/vendor/node/deps/uv/libuv.a obj/vendor/node/deps/http_parser/libhttp_parser.a obj/libatom_lib.a obj/vendor/brightray/libbrightray.a  -Wl,--end-group /tmp/builds/atom-shell/vendor/brightray/vendor/download/libchromiumcontent/Release/libchromiumcontent.so -lpthread -pthread -lgtk-x11-2.0 -lgdk-x11-2.0 -latk-1.0 -lpangoft2-1.0 -lpangocairo-1.0 -lcairo -lpango-1.0 -lfreetype -lfontconfig -lnotify -lgdk_pixbuf-2.0 -lgio-2.0 -lgobject-2.0 -lgmodule-2.0 -lgthread-2.0 -lrt -lglib-2.0 -lm -ldl
c++: error: $ORIGIN: No such file or directory
c++: error: unrecognized command line option '-rpath'
ninja: build stopped: subcommand failed.
```

And that's about as far as I got for now.
I'm closing this since it is more likely a duplicate of #259.
